newsitem.title: JAPAN: MITSUBISHI CONFIRMS EXCLUSION FROM IRAQI OIL TALKS.
newsitem.headline: MITSUBISHI CONFIRMS EXCLUSION FROM IRAQI OIL TALKS.

text.p: Mitsubishi Corp confirmed on Monday that Iraq had decided the trading company and other Japanese oil companies would be excluded from talks on crude oil purchases under the United Nations food-for-oil deal on political grounds.
"The Iraqi government is telling us it will not open negotiations with us until further notice, for strictly political as opposed to economic reasons," a Mitsubishi official said.

On Sunday Iraq's government newspaper al-Jumhouriya quoted Saddam Zeban al-Hassan, head of the State Oil Marketing Organisation (SOMO), as saying that "Iraq excluded a number of contracts with Japanese, British, and Dutch companies.. for the second six months," but provided no official explanation as to why.

"Our negotiator has not been allowed into talks with SOMO, but we are keeping him in Baghdad in order to gather information and wait to see if SOMO will change its mind," the Mitsubishi official said.
He added that the exclusion stemmed from an Iraqi view that Japan had aligned itself too closely with the United States in proceedings related to U.N. sanctions on Iraq.
Iraq is expected to begin its second phase of oil exports under United Nations resolution 986 sometime in the next few days.
Under the plan, Iraq is allowed to sell up to $2.14 billion worth of oil during a 180-day period from June 8 to December 12.
The sale has been delayed due to protracted negotiations between the U.N. and Iraq concerning food-distribution procedures.
Mitsubishi is operating on behalf of Nippon Oil Co Ltd 5001 T, Japan Energy Corp, Kashima Oil Co, and Mitsubishi Oil Co Ltd.

Other Japan firms seeking Iraqi oil are Idemitsu Kosan Co Ltd, which currently has a negotiator in Baghdad, and Cosmo Oil Co Ltd, whose negotiator will arrive in Baghdad on September 5, a company official said.

The official said that market expectations were that the Japanese firms, as well as other excluded companies, would be considered for contracts during the deal's second 90-day period, which begins September 5.
